awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Hierarchical Functioning of River Macrosystems in Temperate Steppes - From Continental to Hydrogeomorphic Patch Scales
awd_abstract_narration:
The need to understand and manage ecosystems at larger regional to continental scale macrosystem levels is becoming increasingly crucial with global climate changes and impacts of exotic plants and animals in freshwater rivers and lakes. Macrosystem management requires an understanding of how different levels of spatial complexity (within a stream reach to entire river valley scales) and biotic organization (populations to ecosystems) affect the functioning of rivers and lakes. The present study will provide this information for 18 rivers spread equally between the two largest temperate steppe biomes of the world: the North American Great Plains and the Euro-Asian Steppes (including those in Mongolia). This project will provide research experiences for under-represented participants (particularly rural and Native American students), stimulate STEM program recruitment in largely under-represented (EPSCoR) states, support some faculty and students at primarily undergraduate institutions, and contribute to scientific education at both graduate and undergraduate institutions in two countries.

These rivers flow through 3 major types of ecoregions within these temperate steppe biomes: mountain steppe shrublands, short-to-tall grasslands, and semi-arid shrublands. Scientists and students from the USA and Mongolia will sample the structure and functioning of these 18 rivers in a variety of hydrogeomorphic areas, such as constricted, meandering, braided, and anastomosing channel sections. Despite their similarity in biome and ecoregional types, the river macrosystems of the Great Plains and the Mongolian steppes vary substantially in fauna, flora, and community through ecosystem functioning. These variations result from differences in climatic patterns, the degree of riverine landscape modification (e.g., by dams, levees, and riparian modification), and the naturalness of the resident fauna. For example, most rivers in the USA contain some dams and many exotic fauna have been introduced, while the vast majority of Mongolian rivers contain no dams and their aquatic fauna is almost exclusively natural and different from those in the USA. Moreover, the Central Asian subcontinental area of Mongolia has one of the strongest warming signals on earth, with air temperatures rising three times faster than the overall northern hemisphere average. Consequently, riverine macrosystems in the USA can help predict changes to Mongolian rivers as a result of pending dam construction and possible species introductions to some rivers, while knowledge of responses of Mongolian macrosystems to more rapid climatic changes can help predict future effects in U.S. rivers. Therefore, this project's goals are to: (a) compare and contrast hierarchical scaling relationships and effects of system drivers and cross-scale interactions on rivers in similar biomes and ecoregions of the two continents; and (b) evaluate effects of climatic changes and anthropogenic disturbance to these river macrosystems.

What are the major goals of the project?

We originally proposed a comparative study of riverine macrosystem functioning which focused on roles of hierarchical scales, system drivers, regional hydrogeomorphology, and changing climates in controlling system metabolism, food webs (including the role of methane), and biodiversity traits of both fish and invertebrates. Our riverine study was designed to encompass four hierarchical scales: (1) temperate steppe biomes on two continents (North American Great Plains and shrubland steppes in the USA and Euro-Asian Steppes of Mongolia); (2) ecoregional basins of temperate steppes (defined here as mountain steppe shrublands, short-to-tall grasslands, and semi-arid shrublands in sink basins); (3) individual rivers and/or major tributaries; and (4) river hydrogeomorphic patches at the valley-to-microshed scale (“functional process zones”, Thorp et al. 2006, 2008), with the last hierarchical scale in our study encompassing contrasting hydrogeomorphic patches with either braided/anastomosing channels or single meandering/constricted channels. We have also been considering responses of riverine macrosystems to inherent ecosystem characteristics, zoogeographic communities, riparian extent, terrestrial landscape characteristics, natural climate differences, and human perturbations to climate, rivers physical structure, and landscape features. We have been focusing on rivers in temperate steppes because: (a) this biome and its rivers are strongly impacted by climate change in Mongolia (see below) and both channel and landscape alterations in the USA, thereby allowing a basis for predicting future impacts in the other continent; and (b) our research team has the extensive background studying U.S. and Mongolian rivers that has enabled us to address the complex questions described below.

 

During the fifth year of the project our primary goals were the following:

 

(1)   Continue the processing of samples from previous expeditions and publish data collected from those expeditions.

(2)   Continue working to enhance research collaborations with a MACRO lab at the National University of Mongolia that is responsible for processing the macroinvertebrate samples collected in Mongolia.

(3)   Support graduate student theses and dissertations at multiple universities of our team members.

(4)   Hold an annual workshop for PIs to discuss the progress of the project and plan the upcoming 2019 expeditions.

(5)   Complete the last six U.S. and Mongolian expeditions

(6)   Expand the scientific collaborations around the project particularly by incorporating international scientists and students.

(7)   Hold regular Skype calls among macroinvertebrate team members.

(8)   Continue sponsoring outreach activities.

(9)   Expand our research activities with studies of the role of methane as a food source in streams using funds from a supplementary grant proposal to NSF.

 

What was accomplished under these Goals?

 

MAJOR ACTIVITIES

All our objectives for the fifth year were accomplished except that the pandemic prevented us from holding the workshop planned for the June 2020 joint meeting of SFS and ASLO in Madison, WI. We have continued Zoom meetings and hope to resume in-person meetings as early as the late spring of 2021, if the pandemic permits such meetings.

 

Publications:

  • Overall, my group published six manuscripts or are in press this last grant year, and others are in review. Those that were published with NSF grant acknowledgment include “at least” the following.
  • Minder, M., E.R. Arsenault, B. Erdenee, and M. Pyron. 2020. Dietary specificity and overlap in endorheic river fishes: How do native and nonnative species compare? J. Fish Biology 97(2): 453-464; https://doi.org/10.1111/jfb.14396
  • Thorp, J.H., W.K. Dodds, C.J. Robbins, A. Maasri, E.R. Arsenault, J.A. Lutchen, G.S. Mathews, F. Tromboni, M. Pyron, B. Hayford, A. Schechner, and S. Chandra. 2020. A framework for lotic macrosystem research. Ecosphere (In Press).
  • Robbins, J. and M. Pyron. 2021. Geomorphological characteristics of the Wabash River, USA: influence on fish assemblages. Ecology and Evolution DOI: 10.1002/ece3.7349
  • Shields, R., M. Pyron, E.A. Arsenault, J.H. Thorp, M. Minder, C. Artz, J. Costello, A. Otgonganbat, B. Mendsaikhan, S. Altangerel, A. Maasri. In press. Geomorphology variables predict fish assemblages for forested and endorheic rivers of two continents. Ecology and Evolution DOI: 10.1002/ece3.8300
  • Maasri, A., M. Pyron, E. Arsenault, J. Thorp, B. Mendsaikhan, F. Tromboni, M. Minder, S. Kenner, J. Costello, S. Chandra, A. Otgonganbat, B. Boldgiv. 2021. Valley-scale hydrogeomorphology drives river fish assemblage variation in Mongolia. Ecology and Evolution DOI: 10.1002/ece3.7505
  • Minder, M., E. Arsenault, B. Erdenee, A. Maasri and M. Pyron. 2021. Diet overlap among nonnative trout species and native Cutthroat Trout (Onchorhynchus clarki) in two U.S. Ecoregions. Ecology and Evolution DOI: 10.1002/ece3.7231
  • Research Expeditions: We completed the last of our planned six research expeditions (3 to USA and 3 to Mongolia) by late 2019 and are now in the process of analyzing the data.
  • We trained multiple graduate students in the U.S. and Mongolia. Completed Masters degree: Jacob Lutchen (KU May 20209); ongoing Masters degree include Karen Gaines (KU); and ongoing Ph.D. degrees (Drexel: Bolortsetseg Erdenee; KU: Emily Arsenault; KSU: Anne Schechner; SDSM&T: John Costello and Battsengel Dashdorj).
  • We continued processing and statistically analyzing river samples from previous expeditions.
